paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Can JWST phase-curve observations of TRAPPIST-1 b differentiate a bare-rock, no-atmosphere planet from an atmosphere-bearing interpretation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed TRAPPIST-1 b phase curve
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Phase-resolved thermal spectra for one rocky exoplanet
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Primary observations include orbital-phase thermal spectra and spectroscopic information for TRAPPIST-1 b.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: No-atmosphere retrieval branch
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Bare-rock model with minimal heat redistribution is used as a falsification test against observed phase/spectral behavior.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere retrieval
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere-bearing retrieval emphasizes CO2 absorption and is compared jointly with phase-curve and spectral data.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere retrieval
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An alternative oxidized atmosphere family is tested because it may remain consistent with the current observations.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study, so results do not establish atmospheric prevalence for all M-dwarf rocky exoplanets.
Retrieval assumptions on circulation, opacities, and clouds/hazes materially affect the quantitative posterior estimates.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features in this kind of phase-curve analysis.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the present TRAPPIST-1 b dataset.
